column2: there is no way of keeping apples quite so good and practicable as packing in light barrels and storing in cool cellars; the barrel forms a room within a room
column3: and prevents circulation of air and consequent drying and shrinking of the fruit
column4: and also lessens the changes of temperature
column5: and besides more fruit can be packed and stored in a given space than in any other way. The poorest of all ways is the large open bin
column6: and the objections are: too much fruit in contact; too much weight upon the lower fruit; and too much trouble to handle and sort when desirable to market. It was formerly the almost universal custom in Western New York to sort and barrel the apples as fast as picked from the trees
column7: heading up at once and drawing to market or piling in some cool place till the approach of cold weather
